questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is evaluated by his pediatrician for 1 week of intermittent hematuria. On examination he appears well developed and well nourished, except a right flank mass is palpable. A biopsy of the mass is performed, which reveals primitive looking small blue cells with glomerular and tubular structures (image). Which of the following indicates poor prognosis for the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anaplasia

 

Option C:

 

Clinical features and history points towards

 

The most common renal malignancy in children is Wilms tumor, usually presented with a palpable mass or hematuria. This tumor, most often caused by a mutation of the WT1 tumor suppressor gene (chromosome 11p13) and is characterized histologically by as a triphasic tumor. The presence of anaplasia is important factor indicating aggressive nature of the tumor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Reduced rate of proliferation actually suggests a better prognosis as it indicates slower tumor growth.

 

Option B: Absence of metastasis is a favorable prognostic factor, not a poor prognostic indicator.

 

Option D: Sparing of basement membrane suggests the tumor is less invasive, which is associated with better outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma):

 

  • Most common malignant renal tumor of childhood (usually before age 5).
  • Classic presentation: asymptomatic abdominal/flank mass; sometimes hematuria, hypertension, or abdominal pain.

 

Histology: so-called triphasic pattern:

 

  • Blastemal component → small round blue cells
  • Epithelial component → primitive tubules and glomeruloid structures
  • Stromal component → fibrous tissue, muscle, cartilage

 

What determines prognosis in Wilms tumor?

 

  • Most patients with Wilms tumor do very well today (survival >90%) thanks to surgery and chemotherapy.
  • But there are certain factors that predict worse prognosis:
    • Anaplasia (unfavorable histology) → the single most important adverse prognostic feature.

 

Characterized by:

 

  • Markedly enlarged, pleomorphic (very variable in size and shape) hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Atypical mitotic figures
  • Indicates genetic instability → leads to chemotherapy resistance.

 

Other factors:

 

  • Older age (>10 years)
  • Large tumor size
  • Tumor rupture before/during surgery
  • Bilateral disease
  • Metastases at diagnosis

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 292

choices.text: Minimal change disease

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest nephropathy seen in a patient with cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous glomerulopathy

Option C:

Membranous Glomerulopathy: This is the correct answer as it is the most common type of nephropathy associated with cancer, particularly solid tumors. It's characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to subepithelial immune complex deposits. Patients often present with nephrotic syndrome.

Explanation:

Option A: Minimal Change Disease: Minimal change disease typically presents with nephrotic syndrome and is most commonly seen in children. It's characterized by the loss of foot processes of podocytes visible under an electron microscope but with normal-appearing glomeruli under a light microscope. It's less commonly associated with malignancies compared to membranous glomerulopathy, although it has been linked with Hodgkin disease.

Option B: IgA Nephropathy: Also known as Berger's disease, IgA nephropathy is marked by IgA immune complexes deposited in the glomerular mesangium. It's not typically associated with malignancy and presents with hematuria, and sometimes with proteinuria.

Option D: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis: FSGS is characterized by scarring in segmented regions of the glomeruli. It can occur as a primary renal disease or secondary to other conditions, including some cancers, but is not the most common cancer-related nephropathy.

Educational Objective:

Membranous glomerulopathy is most commonly linked to malignancies and presents as nephrotic syndrome characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 912)

questions.text: Wilm’s tumor is associated with all of the following except
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral polycystic kidney

Option D:

Bilateral polycystic kidney: Bilateral polycystic kidney is not typically associated with Wilm's tumor. Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a separate genetic disorder characterized by the development of fluid-filled cysts in the kidneys.

Explanation:

Option A: Hemihypertrophy: Wilm's tumor is associated with Beckwith Wiedmann syndrome which has hemihypertrophy as one of the components. Hemihypertrophy is the asymmetric growth of one side or part of the body.

Option B: Aniridia: Aniridia refers to the absence of the iris. Wilm's tumor is associated with WAGR syndrome (Wilm's tumor, Aniridia, Genitourinary anomalies, and mental Retardation).

Option C: Hypertension: Wilm's tumor can cause hypertension due to the secretion of renin by the tumor cells. This can lead to renovascular hypertension.

Educational objective:

Wilm's tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is not associated with bilateral polycystic kidney.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 481)

questions.text: The cytogenetics of chromophilic renal cell carcinoma is characterized by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trisomy 7/17

 

Option C:

 

Chromophilic renal cell carcinoma is a distinct type of RCC. Trisomy 7/17: Trisomy 7/17 is a characteristic cytogenetic aberration found in chromophilic renal cell carcinoma. It is one of the defining features of this subtype.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mutant VHL gene: The VHL gene is commonly associated with clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), not chromophilic RCC.

 

Option B: Loss of 3p: Loss of 3p is a genetic alteration commonly observed in clear cell RCC, not chromophilic RCC.

 

Option D: Loss of 3q: Loss of 3q is also associated with clear cell RCC, not chromophilic RCC.

 

Educational objective:

 

Chromophilic renal cell carcinoma is characterized by specific cytogenetic aberrations, notably loss of the Y chromosome, trisomy / tetrasomy  of chromosomes 7 and 17,

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 950)

questions.text: In Wilm’s tumor, the following finding leads to emergence of resistance to chemotherapy:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplasia

Option C:

Anaplasia: Anaplasia is a histological feature characterized by the presence of cells with large, hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei and abnormal mitoses. It correlates with underlying p53 mutations and is associated with the emergence of resistance to chemotherapy.

  • 5% of tumors reveal anaplasia, defined as the presence of cells with large, hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei and abnormal mitoses and the presence of anaplasia correlates with underlying p53 mutations and the emer­gence of resistance to chemotherapy.

Explanation:

Option A: Nephrogenic rests: Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions seen in Wilms tumor. They are not directly associated with resistance to chemotherapy.

Option B: Monophasic morphology: Monophasic morphology refers to the histological appearance of the tumor, where it predominantly consists of one type of tissue. While it may influence tumor behavior, it is not specifically linked to resistance to chemotherapy.

Option D: Capsular infiltration: Capsular infiltration refers to the invasion of the tumor beyond its encapsulated boundary. While it may indicate a more aggressive tumor behavior, it is not directly linked to resistance to chemotherapy.

Educational objective:

Anaplasia in Wilms tumor, characterized by specific cellular features and associated p53 mutations, leads to the emergence of resistance to chemotherapy, highlighting the importance of recognizing this histological feature for prognosis and treatment planning.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 481)

choices.text: Any of the above

questions.text: Transitional cell carcinoma bladder is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schistosomiasis

Option A:

Schistosomiasis: Schistosomiasis, particularly infection with Schistosoma haematobium, is well-established as a risk factor for the development of bladder cancer, especially in endemic areas such as Egypt and Sudan. The eggs of the parasite are laid in the bladder wall, causing chronic inflammation which can lead to mucosal squamous metaplasia, dysplasia, and potentially neoplasia, often resulting in squamous cell carcinoma.

Explanation:

Option B (Ascariasis): Ascariasis is an infection caused by Ascaris lumbricoides, an intestinal roundworm. It is not typically associated with the development of bladder cancer.

Option C (Malaria): Malaria is caused by Plasmodium parasites. It affects red blood cells and the liver, but it is not associated with the development of bladder cancer.

Educational Objective:

Schistosoma haematobium infection is a significant risk factor for bladder cancer in endemic areas, leading to chronic inflammation and an increased risk of squamous metaplasia, dysplasia, and carcinoma.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 960)

questions.text: Gene associated with superficial papillary urothelial neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) p16

Option B:

(p16): The p16 gene, also known as CDKN2A, encodes for the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p16/INK4a, which is a tumor suppressor that regulates the cell cycle. Deletions affecting the 9p21 region where CDKN2A is located are common in superficial noninvasive papillary tumors of the bladder, making p16 a gene associated with these tumors.

Particularly common (occurring in 30% to 60% of tumors) are losses of genetic material on chromosome 9 (including monosomy or deletions of 9p and 9q). These abnormalities are often the only chromosomal changes present in superficial noninvasive papillary tumors. The 9p deletions (9p20) affects tumor suppressor gene CDKN2A, which encodes the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p16/INK4a and ARF, a protein that augments p53 function.

Explanation:

Option A (p53): The p53 gene is a well-known tumor suppressor gene that is often mutated in a variety of cancers, leading to loss of cell cycle control and enabling the formation of tumors. While p53 mutations are common in many cancers, they are not the most commonly associated gene with superficial papillary urothelial neoplasms.

Option C (p7): There is no well-characterized tumor suppressor gene known as p7 in the context of superficial papillary urothelial neoplasms.

Option D (KRAS): The KRAS gene is an oncogene that can lead to cancer when mutated, as it encodes a protein that is involved in cell signaling pathways that control cell growth. While KRAS mutations can be present in many cancers, they are not the most commonly associated mutation with superficial papillary urothelial neoplasms.

Educational Objective:

Losses of genetic material on chromosome 9, including deletions of 9p21 that affect the CDKN2A gene encoding p16/INK4a, are often the only chromosomal changes present in superficial papillary urothelial neoplasm .

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 958)

questions.text: Most common type of rhabdomyosarcoma is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Embryonal

Option B (Embryonal): Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common type of rhabdomyosarcoma, particularly in infancy and childhood. This subtype often presents as a grapelike mass, especially when occurring in hollow organs like the vagina or urinary bladder, referred to as sarcoma botryoides.

Explanation:

Option A (Pleomorphic): Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is a type of rhabdomyosarcoma that typically occurs in adults and is characterized by a wide variety of cell shapes and sizes. It is not the most common type of rhabdomyosarcoma.

Option C (Alveolar): Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma is less common than the embryonal subtype and has a distinctive histological appearance resembling pulmonary alveoli. It typically occurs in older children and teenagers.

Option D (Botryoid): Botryoid rhabdomyosarcoma is a variant of the embryonal type that manifests as a polypoid, grapelike mass. While it is a recognized subtype, it is not the most common form of rhabdomyosarcoma overall.

Educational Objective:

  • MC sarcoma in infancy or childhood is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. In some cases, it manifests as a polypoid grapelike mass (sarcoma botryoides).
  • MC sarcoma in the bladder in adults is leiomyosarcoma.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 962)

choices.text: Common in adult
Associated with deletion of chromosome 11p13
Associated with MIC-2 genes
Commonest presentation is hematuria

questions.text: True statement regarding Wilms tumour is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Associated with deletion of chromosome 11p13

Option B:

Associated with deletion of chromosome 11p13: Mutations in the WT1 gene, located on chromosome 11p13, are commonly associated with Wilms tumor. Therefore, option B is correct.

Explanation:

Option A: Common in adult: Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) primarily occurs in children, typically between the ages of 2 and 5 years old. It is very rare in adults, so option A is incorrect.

Option C: Associated with MIC-2 genes: MIC-2 gene is not specifically associated with Wilms tumor; instead, it is related to Ewing sarcoma. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D: Commonest presentation is hematuria: The most common presentation of Wilms tumor is an abdominal mass, not hematuria. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

Educational objective:

Wilms tumor is primarily a childhood kidney tumor, commonly associated with mutations in the WT1 gene located on chromosome 11p13, highlighting the genetic basis of this malignancy and aiding in its diagnosis and management.

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 481)

choices.text: Arises from proximal convoluted tubule
More common in females

questions.text: All are true about renal cell cancer except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) More common in females 

Option D:

Renal cell carcinoma has a higher incidence in males compared to females. The male-to-female ratio is approximately 2:1. This gender predilection is observed across various age groups.

Explanation:

Option A: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is known for its propensity to invade nearby structures. The renal vein is commonly involved, and extension into the renal vein is not uncommon in advanced cases. This invasion can potentially lead to the spread of cancer cells to other parts of the body.

Option B: Hematuria is a common symptom of renal cell carcinoma. As the tumor grows, it can invade blood vessels within the kidney, leading to bleeding which is then excreted in the urine. However, it's important to note that not all cases of RCC present with hematuria, and other symptoms such as flank pain or a palpable mass may also be observed.

Option C: RCC typically arises from the proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron. The exact cell type involved is a clear cell carcinoma, which accounts for the majority of RCC cases.

Educational objective :

Renal cell carcinoma has a higher incidence in males compared to females

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 950)

questions.text: VHL syndrome is associated most commonly with which carcinoma:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Renal cell carcinoma

Option B:

The primary tumors associated with VHL syndrome are renal cell carcinoma (RCC), hemangioblastomas of the central nervous system, and pheochromocytomas.

Explanation:

Option A: Lung carcinoma: VHL syndrome is not classically associated with lung carcinoma.

Option C: Endometrial carcinoma: VHL syndrome is not known for an increased risk of endometrial carcinoma.

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma: VHL syndrome is not typically associated with hepatocellular carcinoma.

Educational objective:

VHL syndrome increases the risk of certain tumors, particularly renal cell carcinoma, hemangioblastomas, and pheochromocytomas. A secondary objective is to discern the types of carcinomas not typically associated with VHL syndrome.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 949)

choices.text: Renal cell cancer

questions.text: Pseudohermaphroditism is seen with which of the following tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wilms tumor

Option B:

(Wilms tumor): Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is a childhood kidney cancer. Denys-Drash syndrome is a rare disorder associated with Wilms tumor and is characterized by gonadal dysgenesis, which can present as male pseudohermaphroditism, and nephropathy often leading to renal failure. Abnormalities in the WT1 gene are a hallmark of this syndrome.

Denys-Drash syndrome is characterized by gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudohermaphroditism) and early-onset nephropathy leading to renal failure. The characteristic glomerular lesion in these patients is diffuse mesangial sclerosis. These patients also demonstrate germline abnormalities in WT1.

In addition to Wilms tumors, these individuals are also at increased risk for developing germ cell tumors called gonadoblastomas, almost certainly a consequence of disruption in normal gonadal development.

Explanation:

Option A (Renal cell cancer): Renal cell cancer is not typically associated with pseudohermaphroditism, which is a condition where an individual has reproductive organs or secondary sex characteristics of both sexes.

Option C (Carcinoma lung): Lung carcinoma is a malignant lung tumor characterized by uncontrolled cell growth in tissues of the lung. This condition is not related to pseudohermaphroditism.

Option D (Hepatocellular carcinoma): Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common type of primary liver cancer. It has no direct association with pseudohermaphroditism.

Educational Objective:

Denys-Drash syndrome, which is associated with Wilms tumor, can present with male pseudohermaphroditism due to mutations in the WT1 gene, and this can lead to disorders of sexual development.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 481)
